Alastair Logan (A. H. B. Logan) is senior lecturer at the University of Exeter in England. He has been at the university since 1972 and is the longest standing member of its department of theology.
Dr Logan is a Christian scholar and the chair EFC at the Cathedral Church of Saint Peter in Exeter. He is known for his work regarding Gnosticism in early Christianity. His best-known published work is Gnostic Truth, Christian Heresy, in which he works to redact the Gnostic movement in early Christianity. Logan ties the Gnostic movement to the worship of Seth and contends that the main thrust of the different factions was a rebellion against the religion or religions of the Empires in the Ancient World.

Retiring in 1983, Wilson was the dedicatee of a Festschrift: The New Testament and Gnosis, edited by Alastair Logan and A. J. M. Wedderburn (1983). Wilson translated Kurt Rudolph's German-language study of Gnosticism as Gnosis: The Nature and History of Gnosticism (1984). He wrote Hebrews in 1987 and received the Burkitt Medal for Biblical Studies in 1990. He wrote Colossians and Philemon (2005). Wilson died on 27 June 2010 in Dundee; his wife Enid has died in 2003.Bauckham (2012), pp. 590, 593–597. His papers are held in the University of St Andrews Library Department of Special Collections (MS38376);"Papers of Robert McLachlan Wilson, academic at St Andrews University", University of St Andrews Library Department of Special Collections. Retrieved 27 April 2021. his son donated another cache of Wilson's papers to the Griffith Institute Archive at the University of Oxford (Wilson MSS), where Wilson had already deposited transcripts and notes on New Testament Faiyûmic texts (Kahle MSS 20)."Wilson MSS", Griffith Institute Archive.
